Related Goods

Thesere are two kinds of related goods, namely substitutes and complements. These influence the demand for a good or service.

Substitutes

A substitute is a good that can be used in the place of another good without reducing a consumer's level of satisfaction.

The following are examples of substitutes: butter and margarine, beef and mutton, tea and coffee, rice and wheat, cold drinks and fruit juice, and hamburgers and hot dogs.

Can you think of any other substitutes?

The Dlamini family likes fried chicken, but they also like chicken burgers. Sometimes, instead of buying fried chicken, they buy chicken burgers. Thus, for the family, chicken burgers are a substitute for fried chicken.

Complements

Complements are goods that are often used jointly (together), for example, fish and chips, pap (mealie meal) and boerewors, motor cars and petrol, coffee and milk, flashlights and batteries, DVD machines and DVDs, and cell phones and airtime.
